description: From Middle English frelete, frailte, from Old French fraileté, from Latin fragilitās. Doublet of fragility.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The condition quality of being frail, physically, mentally, or morally; weakness of resolution; liability to be deceived.
examples: the limitations and restraints of civil government, and a legal constitution, may be defended, either from reason, which reflecting on the great frailty and corruption of human nature, teaches, that no man can safely be trusted with unlimited authority ;

entries.meaning: A fault proceeding from weakness; foible; sin of infirmity.
